gold_sents: This is a class-action suit brought by a nonprofit organization and an individual against the state of Georgia to challenge the state’s requirement to purchase postage stamps for mail-in ballots.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring election officials to provide prepaid returnable envelopes for absentee ballots and absentee ballot applications.[SENTMARKER]On April 30, the preliminary injunction was denied for the June primaries and on August 11, the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction was denied as to Count I of the amended complaint, and which was accordingly dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: The plaintiffs filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia on April 8, 2020, against the State of Georgia and the Georgia Department of Elections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Georgia's voter ID laws violated the Fourteenth Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: This suit was brought on May 19, 2020, by two non-profit organizations and three voter plaintiffs against the state of Louisiana to challenge Louisiana’s Excuse Requirement, Witness Requirement, and Cure Prohibition.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief enjoining the defendants from enforcing the Excuse and Witness Requirement, as well as provide absentee voters with notice and opportunity to cure defects in their absentee ballots for all elections in 2020 held in Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]On June 22, the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana by a group of African-American women who alleged that the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals violated their civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate health care.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were denied access to health care because of their race.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in June of this year, with the defendants agreeing to provide health care to African-Americans in the state.

gold_sents: On April 22, four individuals facing a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19 and the Family Unit, a non-profit organization, filed an action against the enforcement of South Carolina’s witness requirement applied to absentee voters, and the excuse requirement applied in order to vote by an absentee ballot.[SENTMARKER]On May 12, the South Carolina General Assembly passed legislation allowing all qualified South Carolina voters to vote by absentee ballot for the June primaries.[SENTMARKER]On May 25, the court granted the plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions in part, pertaining to the witness requirement.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the Witness Requirement was enjoined for the November 2020 General Election in a separate case, and the district court stayed the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought reconsideration.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 22, 2017, a group of South Carolina residents filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's Medicaid program violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide adequate services to those with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now ongoing.

gold_sents: In 2011 voters in Wisconsin filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their fundamental right to vote had been violated by Act 23, Wisconsin's law implementing a voter ID requirement.[SENTMARKER]After much litigation, in 2016 a judge granted a preliminary injunction allowing voters without IDs to sign an affidavit in place of the ID requirement for the 2016 presidential election.[SENTMARKER]The state appealed the injunction to the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit stayed the injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]As of December 2019, the appeal remained pending in the Seventh Circuit.
pegasus_output_sents: The plaintiffs alleged that Wisconsin’s law requiring voters to show a photo ID at the polls was a violation of their Fourteenth Amendment right to equal protection under the law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the Seventh Circuit upheld the district court's decision in favor of the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: On June 21, 2016, individuals who had been forced to pay a $50 "extension fee" for inability to pay their monetary penalties in full, or go to gail for non-payment of court fines and costs, brought a putative class action lawsuit in the District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Bogalusa City Court and the sole judge who sits on the Bogalusa City Court, under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging that the defendants (1) systematically jail and threaten to jail individuals who cannot pay fines and court costs that fund the city court; and (2) have created an illegal extension fee to generate additional revenue.[SENTMARKER]Shortly after U.S. District Court Judge Ivan L.R.[SENTMARKER]Lemelle denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, and held their request for a preliminary injunction in abeyance, the parties decided to explore settlement options.[SENTMARKER]They filed a stipulated agreement with the District Court, which was granted.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 21, 2016, a group of residents of Bogalusa, Louisiana filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the city had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the city agreed to implement corrective measures to ensure compliance with the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 5, 2017.

gold_sents: On October 31st, 2016, a group of Plaintiffs who had been jailed for their inability to pay fines owed to the City of Florissant, Missouri for traffic tickets or other minor municipal offenses, sued the City for this violation of due process.[SENTMARKER]This case is still in the discovery stage and has been ongoing for four years.
pegasus_output_sents: This class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri on October 31, 2016 against the City of Florissant.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were repeatedly jailed by the City because they were unable to pay fines, fees and other costs arising from traffic tickets or other minor municipal offenses.[SENTMARKER]The City moved to dismiss Plaintiffs’ first amended complaint for failure to state a claim, and has also moved for a more definite statement and to strike redundant or immaterial matter, or, in the alternative, to comply with Rules 8(a) and 10(b).

gold_sents: On June 20, 1989, foster care children of the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Children's Rights and the ACLU, asked the court to order improved policies related to protective services, family preservation and preventive services, child placement, case reviews, adoptions, and staffing, among other issues, claiming violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (AACWA), the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, the District of Columbia Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, and the District of Columbia Youth Residential Facilities Licensor Act of 1986.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that caseloads were too large, leaving many children in the foster care system for far too long with unresolved cases.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the complaint alleged inappropriate placements for children and inadequate efforts to return children home.[SENTMARKER]In 1993, Judge Thomas F. Hogan approved a consent decree directing DHS to develop policies and procedures to rectify the system.[SENTMARKER]After many years of oversight, and periodic contempt orders, the system has gradually improved.[SENTMARKER]However, there is still a monitor in place reporting on the progress of the Child and Family Services Agency (CFSA) created as a result of this case.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) on behalf of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and several of its members.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the HHS and DOJ violated the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to comply with a federal court order requiring HHS to provide information on the use of the contraceptive pill.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement agreement in which HHS agreed to provide the information.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the court of appeals on August 31, 2018.

gold_sents: On 2017, foster parents and three states filed a suit challenging the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act (the "ICWA").[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs allege the ICWA violates the Equal Protection Clause and anti-commandeering principles.[SENTMARKER]The district court held the ICWA is unconstitutional which was partially affirmed in a fractured en banc opinion by the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas by a group of Texas residents who alleged that the Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) violated the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to comply with the Texas Open Records Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DPS violated the First Amendment by refusing to provide information to the public about the location of the detention facility where they were held.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on October 25, 2018.

gold_sents: California recipients of Adult Day Health Care services brought this class action to enjoin California from reducing or eliminating the ADHC program, which would put the plaintiffs at risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California granted the plaintiff class a preliminary injunction in September 2009, forbidding California to modify it's adult Day Health Care program until an appropriate alternative could be provided to prevent institutionalization of individuals in the plaintiffs' class.[SENTMARKER]The District Court approved a settlement agreement that created a new program which will help to prevent the institutionalization of ADHC beneficiaries.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 10, 2009, a group of individuals with disabilities filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the California Department of Health Care Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's health care system violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on May 10, 2013.

gold_sents: Two individuals who use wheelchairs for mobility sued the City of Steamboat Springs, for having inaccessible public transportation and facilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree requiring the city to make its services and facilities accessible, pay attorneys' fees and costs, and pay $12,250 to the plaintiffs.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 1999, two individuals with disabilities filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the City of Steamboat Springs, Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City had discriminated against them on the basis of disability in connection with the provision of transit service and certain other City services, in violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 .<n>The parties entered a consent decree in which the City agreed to make its public transportation system accessible to individuals who use wheelchairs.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered on April 20, 2000.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were disabled individuals who sued the Colorado Rockies baseball club after it removed accessible seats in Coors Field and raised prices on others.[SENTMARKER]There was a trial held, after which the court dismissed all claims by stipulation.[SENTMARKER]It is unclear, however, whether the parties settled.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2001, a group of disabled baseball fans filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against Coors Field, the home of the Colorado Rockies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the club violated the Americans With Disabilities Act by making it almost impossible for disabled fans to enjoy a game from front-row or near the infield.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on June 3, 2010.

gold_sents: On April 29, four individuals with disabilities and Disability Rights New York filed a complaint against Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the absence of live televised American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation in Governor Cuomo’s daily televised briefings on COVID-19 discriminated against populations with disabilities residing in New York by failing to provide a live ASL interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, declaring the lack of ASL interpretation as a violation under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO and preliminary injunction requiring the defendant to immediately include live in-frame ASL interpretation for all briefings addressed to New York residents.[SENTMARKER]The preliminary injunction was granted on May 11, and the defendant was ordered to immediately implement live, in-frame ASL interpretation for his daily press briefings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 29, 2020, Disability Rights New York filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo.[SENTMARKER]Andrew Cuomo.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the governor's practice of holding daily press briefings regarding the COVID-19 pandemic without providing simultaneous American Sign Language interpretation for deaf audience members violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1990 (R&A).[SENTMARKER]On May 12, 2020, Judge Valerie E. Caproni granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction and granted their motion for temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2014, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) sued the State of Rhode Island for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide equal employment opportunities (EEO) for people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in a consent decree in which the State agreed to improve its EEO policies and practices.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which Rhode Island agreed to implement a new EEO policy.

gold_sents: In this case, a third-grader plaintiff who had autism and ADHD filed suit against the Kanawha County Schools system under the IDEA, the Rehabilitation Act, Title II of the ADA, the West Virginia Human Rights Act, and West Virginia Policy 2419.[SENTMARKER]The elementary school student had been subject to disciplinary removal from the classroom and his district had failed to provide the behavioral supports and programming required by law.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 24, 2020, the parents of a third-grade student with autism and ADHD filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia against the Kanawha County Schools.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the school had violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) by failing to provide effective behavior supports for their students.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial dismissal of the case on April 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In October 2016, a group of Flint schoolchildren (via their parents) sued the state of Michigan and the school district in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, alleging that the state of Michigan and local educators are in violation of federal law by not screening to identify students who need special education services and violating the rights of students with disabilities in the imposition of school discipline.[SENTMARKER]In April 2018, the parties reached a partial settlement as to one of the plaintiffs' claims, but the rest are still in dispute.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 18, 2016, the ACLU of Michigan filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the Michigan Department of Education (MDE) and the State of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that MDE violated the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to provide equal access to education for children with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which MDE agreed to revise its policies and procedures to ensure equal access.[SENTMARKER]The case is currently pending before the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.

gold_sents: On November 17, 2014, Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina under The Civil Rights Act of 1964, against the University of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief to prohibit the consideration of race in college admissions, claiming that UNC's current admissions policy discriminated against Asian American applicants.[SENTMARKER]The court denied summary judgement and, as of April 9th, 2020, the suit is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 17, 2014, Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. (SFFA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]SFFA alleged that UNC-Chapel Hill’s use of race in its undergraduate admissions process violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (the “Civil Rights Act”) and the North Carolina General Assembly’s prohibition against discrimination in public higher education.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted SFFA's motion for summary judgment on the grounds that the University's policy of using race as a factor in admissions violated the Constitution's equal protection clause.[SENTMARKER]On December 17, 2014, the District Court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: Former students and an employee of Rhinebeck Central High School filed suit against the School District and the former principal alleging that the District had violated Title IX of the Education Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to rectify allegations that the principal had sexually harassed the female students.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a Consent Decree in which the District agreed to implement anti-discrimination procedures.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2006, the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York filed a lawsuit in the U,S.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Columbia against the Rhinebeck Central School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the school district violated Title IX by failing to provide equal opportunities for all female students.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on April 18, 2006, and the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment on March 24, 2014.

gold_sents: A 16-year old transgender male student sued Kenosha Unified School District No. 1 (Kenosha) in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on July 19, 2016, arguing that the school violated the Equal Protection Clause and Title IX by denying Plaintiff access to the boys’ restrooms.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiff a preliminary injunction to use the boys' restroom throughout his senior year, which the Seventh Circuit upheld on May 30, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on January 22, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The settlement required Defendant to pay Plaintiff $800,000, enjoined Defendant from prohibiting Plaintiff from using the boys’ restroom, and required the Defendant to notify all staff about the injunction.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 19, 2016, a student at George Nelson Tremper High School filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the Kenosha Unified School District and its superintendent.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the district violated his First and Fourteenth Amendment rights by failing to provide him with an adequate education.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiff's motion for preliminary injunction, and the district court remanded the case to the Seventh Circuit for further proceedings.

gold_sents: On August 11, 2005 a group of African-Americans filed a consolidated amended complaint Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in United States District Court of the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Wal-Mart discriminated against African-Americans in hiring of over-the-road truck drivers.[SENTMARKER]On May 16, 2007, the court certified a class of African Americans who had not been hired or had been deterred from applying for these jobs.[SENTMARKER]Discovery continued in preparation for trial and on January 13, 2009 the court denied the defendant's motions for decertification and summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties thereafter reached a settlement that was approved by the court on March 5, 2009.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement Wal-Mart agreed to damages in the amount of $17,500,000 to be distributed to the named representatives, class members, and their attorneys.[SENTMARKER]It also agreed to provide EEO training, actively recruit minorities, impose benchmarks for hiring minority drivers, make specific job opportunities open to minorities, and engage in recordkeeping and reporting.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 20, 2006, two employees of Wal-Mart Transportation, Inc. filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were fired because of their race and gender.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on March 3, 2009, and the parties agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice.

gold_sents: This case was brought by female employees of Citigroup Global Markets against Citigroup Global Markets and its subsidiary, Smith Barney, seeking injunctive and declaratory relief and damages for the company's discriminatory practices against female employees.[SENTMARKER]This case was solved by a class-action settlement on August 13, 2008, resulting in relief granted.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 29, 2006, a group of female employees of Citigroup filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (Citigroup) alleging that the company's male employees were paid less than female employees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the male employees' pay was based on their gender, and that Citigroup's female employees were not paid at the same rate as male employees.[SENTMARKER]A jury found in favor of the plaintiffs, and the case was dismissed on February 3, 2008.

gold_sents: On September 25, 2006, the Denver Field Office and the Phoenix District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sued Moreland Auto Group, LLP under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Two former female employees sought injunctive relief to enjoin the defendant from discriminating against employees based on gender or from retaliating against employees who complain about discrimination.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2008 Judge Edward J. Nottingham approved a settlement agreement that included a $70,000 fund to be dispersed amongst the claimants, and an injunction enjoining the defendants from gender-based discrimination.
pegasus_output_sents: This is a public enforcement action to correct the unlawful employment practice of maintaining a hostile work environment based on gender in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, 42 U.S.C. seq. 1981a, and unlawful retaliating against employees.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered an agreement in which the parties agreed to dismiss all claims against each other, except that any claims related to or related to the termination of Lucille Fancher on or about June 3, 2008, were dismissed.

gold_sents: This case was brought by ten black current and former special agents of the United States Secret Service against the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Treasury and the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief including back pay, front pay, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and an injunction, alleging that the Secret Service discriminated against them on the basis of race in promotions as well as in transfers, assignments, testing, hiring, and disciplinary practices.[SENTMARKER]The court approved a settlement agreement that awarded $24 million in damages, $8 million in attorney's fees, and $860,000 in costs.[SENTMARKER]The agreement will remain in place until 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 31, 2006, a group of African-American plaintiffs filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HHS violated the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to provide the plaintiffs with adequate notice of HHS's proposed changes to the Affordable Care Act (ACA).[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought by eight Hispanic Special Agents against the U.S. Department of Treasury's United States Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and injunctive relief, alleging there was a pattern and practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin by the U.S. Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted Defendant's Motion for Summary Judgment on March 20, 2007, thereby terminating the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 10, 2002, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Department had violated the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 16, 2006, and the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed suit against Yellow Transportation, Inc., and YRC, Inc., for discriminatory employment practices on behalf of 14 current or former black employees and the class of similarly situated black employees.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Yellow Transportation (later merged into YRC) had violated §703(a) of Title VII, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-2(a) by subjecting black employees to greater scrutiny, more frequent and greater discipline, lower paying and less favorable job assignments, more difficult and time-consuming work, and a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive and monetary relief, including economic and noneconomic harm to the employees, punitive damages, development of policies and programs to provide equal employment opportunity and eradicate the effects of its past discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC also sought to recover its costs.[SENTMARKER]The charging parties later intervened as plaintiffs on their own behalf, adding claims for retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement, which was entered as a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree resolved this case and the related case Brown v. Yellow Transportation, Inc. , linked below (Clearinghouse code: EE-IL-0329).[SENTMARKER]The decree awarded a total of $11 million ($1.1 million in attorney's fees) and no significant injunctive relief because of a consent decree in other litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case is technically open but effectively closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 10, 2009, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against Yellow Transportation, Inc. and YRC Inc.<n>The EEOC alleged that Yellow Transportation subjected African-American employees to racial harassment and discrimination in violation of Title VII and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, as amended.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which Yellow Transportation agreed to correct unlawful employment practices on the basis of race and to provide appropriate relief to a class of Black employees.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs sued Sprint, alleging ADEA violations pursuant to 29 U.S.C. § 621, the ADA, and 42 U.S.C. §12203.[SENTMARKER]Class comprised just under 1,700 members.[SENTMARKER]Eventually, parties reached $57 million settlement agreement.

Section 2000e-a, against AdvanceMed Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The Commission alleged that AdvanceMed rejected Denise Gaston, a black female, for the position of Chief Nurse because of her race.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Commission's motion for preliminary injunction, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The agreement was entered into on June 11, 2005.

gold_sents: This is a race discrimination class action brought by black police officers in Baltimore, alleging discriminatory discipline and hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in December 2004, and settled in June 2009 for $2.5 million in damages to the 15 named plaintiffs and injunctive relief for the class.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 13, 2005, a group of African-American employees of the Baltimore City Police Department filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the City of Baltimore and the State of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City had violated the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on June 23, 2009, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In 2005, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the City of Pontiac and the local firefighters' union.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that the collective bargaining agreements entered by the Pontiac Fire Department and the local firefighters' union discriminated on the basis of sex and race by explicitly creating and maintaining a dual system for hire and promotion requiring that one out of every thee hires or promotions be given to a minority.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the DOJ and the City of Pontiac reached a settlement that required the City of Pontiac to not engage in any act or practice that discriminated on the basis of race or sex in violation of Title VII in relation to hiring or promotion in the Pontiac Fire Department and to provide remedial relief to those employees and applicants denied hire or promotion as a result of the dual system for hire and promotion.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in October 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 28, 2006, the U.S. Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the Eastern District of Michigan against the City of Pontiac, Michigan vn, and the International Association of Fire Fighters (IAFF) in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by discriminating against African-American and Hispanic employees of the Pontiac Fire Department.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 28, 2006 by the Judge George Caram Steeh.

gold_sents: On August 29, 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed suit in the Albuquerque U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico against Bell Gas, Inc. and related corporations on behalf of a female employee.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the companies had violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.) by subjecting the employee to a sexually hostile work environment created by verbal and physical harassment from her immediate supervisor, including sexual assault.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree, which provided the employee received a total of $180,000; $60,000 up front and monthly payments of $2,000 for 60 months-and subjected Defendants to an array of injunctive provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 16, 2019, the ACLU filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Justice and the Attorney General of the United States.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government's policy of detaining illegal immigrants in the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant violated the due process and equal protection guarantees of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On December 17, 2020, the court granted a stay of enforcement of the policy pending further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On January 28, 2019, the Supreme Court issued a ruling in favor of the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: On August 16, 2019, several health care providers and nonprofit organizations serving immigrant communities filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Department of Homeland Security's Final Public Charge Rule (the Rule), which added non-cash benefits to the factors considered in determining whether a person applying for legal permanent residence is likely to become a public charge.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Government violated the Administrative Procedure Act by exceeding its statutory authority, claimed that the Rule was "arbitrary and capricious," and asserted that the Rule violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, a district court judge denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction enjoining the government from implementing the Rule, but issued an order for preliminary injunction in a related case that would enjoin the implementation of the rule in California, Oregon, the District of Columbia, Maine, and Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]This preliminary injunction was stayed by the Ninth Circuit in December 2019.[SENTMARKER]It was affirmed a year later in December 2020, but the order was stayed pending petitions to the Supreme Court in the Second, Seventh, and Ninth Circuits.[SENTMARKER]The Rule was abandoned by DHS on March 9, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of April 15, 2021, the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: This is a class action lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a South Carolina immigration law which requires state and local law enforcement officers to investigate the immigration status of any individual they stop, detain, or arrest whenever they have a "reasonable suspicion" that the individual lacks immigration status, allows law enforcement officers to arrest individuals solely for failing to carry registration documents, makes it a crime to harbor or transport an undocumented immigrant or to be harbored or transported by others if one is an undocumented immigrant, and imposes civil liability on the police for failing to enforce its provisions to the maximum extent possible.[SENTMARKER]The law was patterned after Arizona's SB 1070.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the law, and this injunction has been appealed to the Fourth Circuit; in the meantime, the case, along with several others like it from different states, are stayed at the District Court or U.S.[SENTMARKER]Appellate level pending the decision of the Supreme Court in United States v. Arizona.[SENTMARKER]After Arizona v. United States was decided the issue was remanded to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court left in place most of its original preliminary injunction, enjoining the state from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6 (B)(2).[SENTMARKER]The 4th Circuit per Judge Davis agreed and affirmed the order on July 13, 2013.[SENTMARKER]In March of 2014 Judge Gergel permanently enjoined South Carolina from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6(B)(2).[SENTMARKER]Furthermore the state agreed to more favorable interpretations of Section 7, and the remainder of Section, encouraging the Plaintiffs to dismiss their claims on those sections without prejudice.

gold_sents: The Disability Rights Network (DRN), a Pennsylvania non-profit, filed this Eighth Amendment suit against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) for the PDOC's use of solitary confinement with severely mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement for dismissal of the matter, in which the PDOC agreed to implement certain improvements and to pay $750,000 to DRN.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the PDOC will evaluate all incoming prisoners for serious mental illness, and will place prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement only in "exceptional" circumstances; even then, a prisoner with serious mental illness can be kept in solitary confinement for no longer than 30 days and must be allowed out of their cells for 20 hours per week.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a monitor to report on compliance, and will remain in effect for 3 years (less if the defendant demonstrates substantial compliance for a period of 18 months).[SENTMARKER]There has been no activity on the docket since May 2015 and the case is presumably closed since the three year time period set in the agreement has lapsed.

gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.

gold_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents separated from their children filed a civil action against various federal agencies and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for immediate reunification with their children.The plaintiffs were detained after crossing the United States-Mexico border without inspection with young accompanying children, seeking asylum.[SENTMARKER]After plaintiffs were apprehended at the border, the children were separated under the “zero-tolerance” immigration policy announced April 6, 2018, which criminally prosecuted adult entrants crossing the border illegally and placed accompanying minors in custody of the government.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs crossed the border prior to the Executive Order issued on June 20, 2018, which allowed immigrant parents and children apprehended at the border to remain together during the pendency of their proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged interference of family integrity in violation of Due Process, and sought preliminary and permanent injunctions to immediately reunite plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs obtained preliminary relief and were (along with another parent who joined the case later to prevent separation from her daughter) ultimately re-united with their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 20, 2018, a mother and her nine-year-old son filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the United States Attorney's Office for the Western District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction requiring the DHS to reunify the plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]On September 10, 2018, the Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed on October 2, 2018.

gold_sents: This action, filed Jan.[SENTMARKER]31, 2017, challenges President Trump’s Jan.[SENTMARKER]27, 2017 Executive Order ban on admission to the U.S. of nationals of Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, detained pursuant to the EO.[SENTMARKER]If the plaintiff cannot return to the U.S., he faces the risk of being deported to Syria, where he is a citizen but has never been a resident.[SENTMARKER]That gold_sents: In 2020, two immigration detainees in the Batavia Federal Detention Facility in Batavia, NY, filed this class action in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they and others similarly situated had been improperly denied bond, that non-bond alternatives to detention had not been properly considered by their immigration judges, that such considerations were required by the Immigration and Nationality Act, and that the policy of placing the burden of proof on the Plaintiffs to show they posed no flight risk violated their Fifth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted relief for pre-hearing detainees, agreeing that they pled sufficient facts to state a Due Process Claim that the government is required to bear the burden of proof at bond hearings for individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. §1226(a).[SENTMARKER]It denied Plaintiffs' request to certify the putative post-hearing class.[SENTMARKER]Both parties appealed; the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: This suit seeks to support Texas's law Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the suits that seek to challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order, this suit aims to support the work of federal immigration officials.[SENTMARKER]There are, so far, four cases addressing SB4.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2017, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed this suit seeking a declaratory judgment approving SB4.[SENTMARKER]Defendants are Travis County, City of Austin, and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF).[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction on May 24, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice to refiling on August 9, 2017, finding that Texas lacked actual or imminent injury, which was required for Article III standing to seek declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Texas appealed to the Fifth Circuit, who affirmed the district court's dismissal of the claim on December 12, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: Two detainees in Shelby County Jail in Tennessee filed this petition for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that failure to take sufficient COVID-19 precautions violated the Fourteenth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and they sought release.[SENTMARKER]The court appointed an "Independent Inspector" to assess conditions at the jail and, based on his report, denied preliminary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied defendants' motion to dismiss, and a trial is scheduled for May 2021.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Inspector was tasked with inspecting the jail to evaluate the conditions.[SENTMARKER]While praising defendants' professionalism, he wrote that several adjustments needed to be made in order for the jail to be a safe place for detainees.[SENTMARKER]After attending mediation and filing a joint motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement, the court preliminarily granted the consent decree requiring monthly reports on the status of COVID-19 in the Jail and unannounced, periodic inspections by the Inspector.[SENTMARKER]A final approval hearing is scheduled for March 5, 2021.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2014, the Board ofDirs.[SENTMARKER]of Rotary Int'l sued the U.S. Department of Justice in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California for violations of the Freedom of Information Act (F.I.A.)[SENTMARKER]and the Constitution's Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]The club alleged that the government had violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments by refusing to provide information on the location of the club's headquarters.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the government's motion to dismiss, and the case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2015, the Supreme Court remanded the case to the lower courts for further consideration.

Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The Sixth Circuit remanded the case to the District Court to consider the parties' arguments.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 7, 1999, a group of women filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his law firm.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Giuliani's law firm had violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by discriminating against them on the basis of their race and gender.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case, but the Second Circuit upheld the district court's dismissal of the case.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States later remanded the case to the lower court.

gold_sents: This case was brought by Disability Advocates, Inc. against the Governor of the State of New York seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to compel Defendant to provide services in the most integrated setting appropriate.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued judgment in favor of Plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]After the Defendants appealed, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit vacated the judgment of the District Court and dismissed the action due to lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ continued to pursue a settlement.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2013, the State and the DOJ filed a settlement to provide approximately 4000 qualifying adult home residents the option of living in community-supported private homes scattered throughout New York City.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved in March 2014.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was amended and changed several times from 2014 to 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing and the court maintains jurisdiction.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, the Department of Justice filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York on behalf of private plaintiffs who alleged that the federal government's Medicaid program violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide adequate health care to those who need it.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought monetary and other relief, as well as a permanent injunction against the government.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and the parties reached a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs are lesbian couples who filed suit on November 3, 2004 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma, against the United States and the State of Oklahoma, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and Article 2 § 35 of the Oklahoma Constitution (the "Oklahoma Amendment") violate the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that DOMA and the Oklahoma Amendment violates the Due Process, Equal Protection, Full Faith and Credit, and Privileges and Immunities Clauses of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court found for the plaintiffs, holding on Jan.[SENTMARKER]14, 2014 that the ban on same-sex marriage violated the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit found for the plaintiffs on July 18, 2014, and after the Supreme Court denied a petition for a writ of certiorari (on October 6, 2014), the Court lifted the stay on its original mandate and enjoined the Defendant from enforcing the Oklahoma Amendment and denying same-sex couples marriage licenses.[SENTMARKER]The Court awarded $309,485.27 in attorney's fees to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 3, 2004, a group of Oklahoma residents filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Justice (DOJ) violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by denying them the right to equal protection under the law.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on July 18, 2014 with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought by workers with limited English proficiency, whose jobs were lost or threatened by foreign competition against the U.S. Department of Labor, seeking injunctive relief, a declaratory judgment and costs for the DOL's failure to provide adequate training under the Trade Act of 1974.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on December 30, 2005 and resulted in the establishment of a program for Limited English-Proficient workers in the El Paso area by the DOL as well as widespread policy changes as to the administration of the job training benefits.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 6, 2005, a group of workers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the Department of Labor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Labor Department had violated the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) by failing to provide job training to thousands of workers who lost their jobs after the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) between Mexico and the United States.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on June 17, 2005.

gold_sents: On September 13, 2013, an African American inmate in the Arizona State Prison Complex in Tucson filed this lawsuit against the State of Arizona and the Arizona Department of Correction in the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]He sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the prison segregated him by race, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on December 22, 2015, under which the defendants would narrowly limit racial consideration in prison housing and employment opportunities, and pay $5,000 in monetary damages to plaintiff as well as $195,000 to plaintiff’s counsel in attorneys’ fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 13, 2013, a prisoner at the Arizona State Prison 15 Complex, Santa Rita Unit, in Tucson, Arizona, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the Arizona Attorney General's Office and the Arizona Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants had violated his civil rights by failing to provide him with adequate food, medical care, and other services.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on February 5, 2016.

gold_sents: In 2005, a group of California prisoners with mental illness filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation alleging that the prison system's policies regarding prisoners with mental disabilities violated the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled in 2015 and the court retained jurisdiction to enforce the terms of the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 12, 2007, a group of plaintiffs filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the department had violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by denying them the right to equal protection under the law.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2014, Disability Rights Florida filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that certain inmates with mental illness at Dade Correctional Institution had been subject to torture, beatings, verbal harassment and food deprivation in violation of their Eighth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that these inmates had received insufficient care in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Federal Rehabilitation Act. Disability Rights Florida requested declaratory and injunctive relief to deem these practices unlawful and unconstitutional, and assurance that such practices would not continue.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement which required improved conditions for prisoners and ran through November 2017.[SENTMARKER]Subsequent litigation in this case resulted from its consolidation with a related civil rights case seeking monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]That portion of the litigation settled for $4.5 million in 2018.[SENTMARKER]As of July 2020, the court retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 9, 2014, Disability Rights Florida, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the Florida Department of Corrections (FDOC) on behalf of its clients and constituents.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the FDOC had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (RFRA) by failing to provide the plaintiffs with adequate medical care.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on March 10, 2017, and the parties agreed to a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Deaf inmate at the Georgia Department of Corrections filed lawsuit for injunctive relief in the form of communication aids and damages for pain and suffering.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following a show cause order from the judge suggesting that case should be consolidated with a nearly identical case.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 3, 2016, two prisoners at Central State Prison in Macon, Georgia, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Georgia against the Georgia Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated their civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate medical care.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, two Missouri Medicaid recipients filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri after being denied medication to treat their Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Missouri Department of Social Services and MO HealthNet denied medically necessary treatment to Medicaid beneficiaries with Hepatitis C, discriminated against similarly situated Medicaid beneficiaries, failed to provide "reasonably prompt" treatment, violated due process, and violated the American with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In November 2017, MO HealthNet modified its policies and the case was dismissed as moot without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in November 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 18, 2016, two Medicaid recipients with Hepatitis C virus (HCV) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri against the Missouri Department of Social Services (DSS) and the Missouri HealthNet Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DSS's policies and practices violated their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights to equal protection under the law and due process.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss the case on February 2, 2017.

gold_sents: Four incarcerated women alleged that their First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights were violated by being housed in the same facilities as transgender women.[SENTMARKER]After years of litigation, the claims were eventually dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 3, 2017, a group of female prisoners filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the United States Department of Justice and the Bureau of Prisons.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated their constitutional rights by failing to provide adequate medical care and treatment to female prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on July 11, 2018.

gold_sents: This case was filed by a trans woman incarcerated in a men's prison in Washington State on September 5, 2017 in the District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleges that the blanket policy in the Washington Department of Correction denying prisoners access to gender affirming surgery amounts to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]She is represented by the ACLU, and is seeking injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a preliminary settlement agreement on March 20, 2020, and proceedings were stayed for 180 days in an attempt to implement the agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 5, 2018, a prisoner filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Washington Department of Corrections and the Department of Juvenile Justice.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his constitutional rights by failing to provide him with adequate mental health treatment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Three indigent persons charged with crimes filed a class action lawsuit in Skagit County Superior Court against the City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington alleging defendants failed to provide adequate assistance of counsel.[SENTMARKER]The Cities jointly contracted with two attorneys to handle all public defense assistance cases, and each attorney handled over 1,000 cases per year.[SENTMARKER]The Court found the plaintiffs established their rights were systematically deprived and the Cities were responsible for the deprivation.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief requiring the City of Mount Vernon and City of Burlington re-evaluate their contract for the provision of public defense services and hire one part-time public defense supervisor.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 5, 2011, a group of residents of Mount Vernon, Washington filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the city had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by denying them equal access to public services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the grounds that the ADA does not apply in this case.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on April 15, 2014.

gold_sents: On November 13, 2018, CNN and CNN’s chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta sued President Trump and several senior members of his administration for violating his First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking his White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]under The plaintiffs sued under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgments Act, arguing that defendants violated the Constitution and APA when they revoked Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting that the court require the defendants to restore Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on November 19, 2018 after the Trump administration returned Acosta's White House press credentials to him.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 13, 2018, CNN and two other news organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the White House, the Secret Service, and the Department of Justice.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the President's "hard pass" policy violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Constitution's Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]On November 20, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On February 18, 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment.

gold_sents: When mass protests against police violence were exempted from New York’s COVID-19 gathering restrictions, but congregational worship continued to be prohibited, two Catholic priests and three Orthodox Jews brought this lawsuit, alleging that New York officials were discriminating against people of faith.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 26, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 10, 2017, a group of gay men and women filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York against the New York State Department of Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's anti-gay discrimination laws violated their constitutional rights under the Fourteenth Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on October 10, 20.

gold_sents: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 29, 1973, teachers in Detroit, Michigan, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the State of Michigan and the Michigan Board of Education.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state had violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by denying them equal protection under the law.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, holding that the district court had erred in denying the plaintiffs a preliminary hearing.
